docs.lead_paragraph: Without even a nod to President Clinton, who delivered his valedictory speech to Democrats in Los Angeles tonight, Vice President Al Gore struck populist themes today in two appearances and pledged to ''stand up for what's right'' for the country. Mr. Gore was introduced at a humid open-air rally here tonight within view of the city's landmark Gateway Arch by his running mate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, as a ''decent and honest'' man. But neither referred to the president, whose administration's policies they have both generally supported and want to perpetuate, but whose private behavior they have both criticized.

headline.main: Gore and Lieberman Voice Populist Themes

docs.abstract: Democratic presidential candidate Vice Pres Al Gore and running mate Sen Joseph Lieberman strike populist themes during campaign appearances in St Louis without mentioning Pres Clinton; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of President Clinton's speech to the Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen. Isn't it great to be here in California together? Forty years ago, the great city of Los Angeles launched John Kennedy and the New Frontier. Now, Los Angeles is launching the first president of the new century: Al Gore.

headline.main: Clinton's Address to Party: Extolling 8 Years of Change in America

docs.abstract: Transcript of Pres Clinton's speech to Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton celebrated her husband's years in office and proclaimed her faith in Al Gore to an audience of thousands of cheering Democrats tonight. She also used the moment to advance her bid for the Senate as she luxuriated in a level of attention unimaginable for a candidate conducting her first campaign for public office. By the time Mrs. Clinton arrived at the Democratic National Convention hall here, she had already been interviewed by all three network anchors for segments on the evening news, as well as by CNN's Larry King. It was a feast of prime-time exposure that left her aides ecstatic, surpassed only by the 17 minutes in prime time she enjoyed before a partisan audience that applauded her review of her years in the White House and her mention of the political career she has embarked upon in running for senator from New York.

headline.main: For Mrs. Clinton, a National Stage To Promote a Candidate, or Two

docs.abstract: First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton celebrates husband's years in office and proclaims her faith in Al Gore to cheering audience of thousands at Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles; uses moment to advance bid for US Senate; frames praise for Gore and Democratic Party in ways that reinforce issues in her campaign and attacks against opponent Repr Rick Lazio; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the warmth of daylight, as I held our brand-new first child, the night before seemed far away. It was the day after we brought Bess home from the hospital -- her insurance-mandated 48-hour stay had expired all too quickly -- and it was time for my wife and me to begin our new role as parents. Bess was born two weeks early. In the hospital she was still fatigued by the ordeal of birth and easily calmed. A soothing caress, a few words in a deep voice or, more practically, her mother's breast were all that were needed to settle her down to sleep. This is going to be simple, I thought, as I looked forward to being the father of the mythical easy baby.

headline.main: A Baby Works Her Magic on an Expert

docs.abstract: Dr Howard Markel comments ruefully on discovering that actually having a newborn daughter is far cry from writing baby-care books as bachelor pediatrician (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Al Gore has been hovering outside California waiting for the Clintons to depart, like a host tapping his foot at the door while the longest-winded guest at the party launches into one last anecdote by the coat rack. But now the convention is his, his, his, and we are going to hear more about Mr. Gore over the next three days than you might have thought humanly possible. One of the major topics of speculation has been how many times the organizers can manage to remind voters that Mr. Gore served in Vietnam, unlike some presidential candidates we could name. The answer, it appears, is around fifteen jillion. They are, in fact, planning to devote an entire day to the salute to Vietnam veterans. Did we mention that Mr. Gore volunteered?

headline.main: Public Interests; Al Gore Marches In

docs.abstract: Gail Collins Op-Ed column on Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles says more is going to heard about Al Gore in coming days than one would think humanly possible, and absolutely nothing is going to happen without assistance of a famous entertainer; says country is moving into new territory with Pres Clinton's farewell speech, and next president, whoever he is, is not likely to shock, appall, mystify or interest us the way Clinton did
